title: Acne Purging - What it is and what it means
author: madaesthetics

sections.content: The pursuit of blemish free skin can lead us down a path of products and treatments, with an array of ingredients promising transformative results. However, sometimes these solutions seem to backfire, leading to a curious phenomenon known as skin purging. In this blog post, I want to explore the science behind skin purging and discuss its implications for our skincare journey.
What is Skin Purging?

Skin purging occurs when an active ingredient in a skincare product accelerates the skin's natural shedding process, causing existing microcomedones (tiny, non-inflammatory acne lesions) to surface more quickly. While it might initially appear counterintuitive, this process can be beneficial in the long run.

To understand skin purging, let's first delve into the science of the skin. Our skin goes through a continuous cycle of renewal, shedding dead cells and creating new ones. This process, known as desquamation, takes roughly 28 days for the average adult. However, factors such as age, environment, and product use can impact this timeline.

Active ingredients, such as retinoids, alpha and beta hydroxy acids (AHAs and BHAs), and benzoyl peroxide, are commonly found in skincare products designed to treat acne and promote skin cell turnover. When introduced to the skin, these ingredients may cause a rapid acceleration of the desquamation process, expediting the appearance of microcomedones on the skin's surface.

Although it might seem counterproductive, skin purging is actually a sign that the product is doing its job. By bringing underlying issues to the surface, the active ingredients in these products help to clear out existing congestion and promote healthier skin over time. The key is to remain patient and trust the process.
How to Differentiate Between Purging and Breakouts

It's essential to recognize the difference between skin purging and a regular breakout, as the two require distinct approaches. Skin purging is a temporary reaction to an active ingredient, whereas breakouts can result from various factors, such as hormones, stress, or using comedogenic (pore-clogging) products.
Here are some pointers to help differentiate between the two:

Observe the location of the breakouts: If you notice acne emerging in areas where you usually experience congestion, it's likely to be skin purging. However, if you develop breakouts in unfamiliar areas, it may be an adverse reaction to the product.

Monitor the duration: Skin purging typically lasts between 4-6 weeks, as this is the average time needed for skin cell turnover. If the breakouts persist beyond this timeframe, it may indicate that the product is not suitable for your skin. However, the life cycle of acne is up to 90 days, so in some cases purging can continue. Always consult with your aesthetician before taking yourself off of a product!
Consider the ingredients: If the product contains known purging agents like retinoids, AHAs, BHAs, or benzoyl peroxide, the breakouts are more likely to be due to skin purging.
How to Manage Skin Purging
While skin purging can be frustrating, remember that it's a temporary phase in the journey to healthier skin. To ease the process, follow these steps:
Be patient: Give your skin time to adjust to the new product. Don't be disheartened if you don't see immediate results.
Keep your skincare routine simple: Avoid overloading your skin with additional active ingredients during the purging process.
Don't pick or squeeze: As tempting as it may be, resist the urge to pick or squeeze the purging acne. Doing so can lead to inflammation, scarring, and even a longer healing time.

Consult your aesthetician: If you're unsure whether your skin is purging or experiencing an adverse reaction, it's best to consult a professional. They can provide expert advice on how to manage the situation and recommend suitable products for your skin type and concerns.

Skin purging is a natural and often beneficial process that occurs as our skin adjusts to new products containing active ingredients. Though it may be disheartening to experience breakouts, understanding the science behind purging and differentiating it from regular acne can help us navigate this temporary phase with patience and confidence. By embracing a simple, supportive skincare routine and working with a skin care professional, we can make meaningful progress towards a clearer and healthier complexion!

title: What is dermaplaning and how does it differ from shaving
author: madaesthetics
bannerAlt: Maddie the esthetician performing a dermaplaning procedure on a client.

sections.content: Dermaplaning has been gaining popularity in the skincare world, and you might have stumbled upon it on your social media feed. It's a non-invasive, quick, and effective procedure that uses a medical-grade scalpel to exfoliate the top layer of your skin gently. While it may sound daunting, dermaplaning is painless and has a wide range of benefits, including brighter and softer skin. You may be curious about why dermaplaning is necessary when shaving can serve the same purpose. In this article, we'll explore the unique benefits of dermaplaning and why it's different from a typical shave.

sections.alt: Maddie the esthetician performing a dermaplaning procedure on a client.

sections.content: Dermaplaning Benefits

One of the primary advantages of dermaplaning is that it exfoliates your skin deeply and effectively, removing up to 2 weeks of dead skin cells and debris buildup. This, in turn, can help to unclog your pores, reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles, and promote healthy, glowing skin.

Another significant benefit of dermaplaning is that it can make your skin more receptive to other skin care treatments, such as serums and moisturizers. By removing the top layer of dead skin cells, these products can penetrate your skin more effectively, delivering their active ingredients where they are needed most. This can help to increase the effectiveness of your overall skin care routine and help you achieve your desired results more quickly.

sections.alt: Maddie the esthetician cleaning a clients skin in preparation for dermaplaning.

sections.content: Dermaplaning is also a great option for anyone looking to improve the overall appearance of their skin quickly and easily. Unlike some other skin care treatments, dermaplaning requires no downtime and is virtually pain-free. It's a quick procedure that can be done in as little as 30 minutes, making it an excellent option for anyone looking for a simple, effective, and non-invasive way to improve their skin.
Dermaplaning vs. Shaving

While dermaplaning and shaving seem similar on the surface, dermaplaning is a more intensive treatment that is specifically designed to exfoliate your skin more deeply and effectively. While shaving can remove some of the dead skin cells on the surface of your skin, it cannot provide the same benefits as dermaplaning, such as unclogging pores and promoting healthy, glowing skin.

Dermaplaning is an excellent option for anyone looking to improve the overall appearance and health of their skin quickly and easily. If you're interested in dermaplaning or have any other questions about this treatment, don’t hesitate to reach out! With the right care and attention, dermaplaning can be an incredibly effective way to achieve healthy, beautiful skin that you'll be proud to show off.

title: The importance of spf while treating acne
author: madaesthetics

sections.content: The importance of using SPF while treating acne or using acne-targeting ingredients cannot be overstated. Not only does SPF help protect the skin from harmful UV rays, which can worsen acne and lead to skin aging and other skin issues, it is also an important part of any acne treatment regimen.

When it comes to acne, it's important to remember that the sun can be both a friend and a foe. On one hand, a little bit of sunlight can be beneficial for the skin - it can help stimulate the production of vitamin D, which is essential for healthy skin. On the other hand, too much sun exposure can be damaging, especially for those with acne-prone skin.

UV rays from the sun can stimulate the production of oil in the skin, which can lead to clogged pores and breakouts. Additionally, the heat and humidity that often accompany sunny days can make acne worse by causing sweat and excess oil production. Sun exposure can also lead to inflammation and irritation, which can further aggravate acne-prone skin.

In addition to the potential negative effects of the sun on acne, it's important to consider the impact that certain acne-targeting ingredients can have on the skin's sensitivity to UV rays. Many acne treatments, such as benzoyl peroxide and salicylic acid, can increase the skin's sensitivity to the sun. This means that using these types of products without proper sun protection can lead to sunburn, skin irritation, and other skin issues.

That's where SPF comes in. Using a broad-spectrum SPF product, which protects against both UVA and UVB rays, is essential for protecting the skin while using acne-targeting ingredients. It's important to apply SPF every day, even on cloudy or overcast days, as UV rays can still penetrate the clouds and damage the skin. It's also important to remember to reapply SPF every two hours, or immediately after swimming or sweating.

Hyperpigmentation, or the darkening of certain areas of the skin, can be a concern for those with acne-prone skin. Acne itself can cause hyperpigmentation, as the inflammation caused by acne can lead to the production of excess melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin. Sun exposure can also worsen hyperpigmentation, as UV rays can stimulate the production of melanin and cause existing hyperpigmentation to become more pronounced.

Using SPF can help to prevent hyperpigmentation by protecting the skin from the harmful effects of UV rays. In addition to using SPF, it may be helpful to incorporate other skincare products into your routine that are formulated to address hyperpigmentation, such as vitamin C serums or pigment inhibitors. By taking these precautions, you can help to prevent hyperpigmentation and maintain a clear, even skin tone.

In summary, using SPF is an important part of any acne treatment regimen. Not only does it protect the skin from the harmful effects of UV rays, it also helps to prevent irritation and other skin issues that can be caused by certain acne-targeting ingredients. By incorporating SPF into your daily skincare routine, you can help protect your skin from sun damage and keep your acne under control.

title: What is a Hydrafacial and why should you get one
author: madaesthetics

sections.content: If there’s one skin treatment you should book yourself before an event or for instant results - it’s a HydraFacial. HydraFacials are a multi-step treatment that uses a machine with a special tip to deliver a blend of serums to the skin. It’s painless, luxurious and totally customizable. The machine exfoliates dead skin cells and removes impurities, leaving the skin feeling smooth and refreshed, and the serums nourish and hydrate the skin, helping to boost its overall health and appearance.
How it works

A HydraFacial machine is designed to deliver a series of specialized serums to the skin using a patented spiral-design tip. The tip has multiple levels of exfoliation, which allows for gentle removal of dead skin cells, deep cleansing, and the delivery of hydration to the skin.

HydraFacials are designed to be both gentle and effective, making them suitable for a wide range of skin types and concerns. The level of suction and pressure can be adjusted to suit individual skin needs, and the machine’s tip can be easily swapped out to target specific concerns, such as hyperpigmentation or fine lines.
Process

The treatment typically starts with a gentle exfoliation to remove dead skin cells and reveal a brighter, smoother complexion. This is followed by a deep cleansing process that removes impurities and unclogs pores. The suction created by the machine also helps to remove impurities, blackheads, and whiteheads, leaving the skin looking clear, refreshed and insanely glowy! The final step involves the delivery of a nourishing serum that hydrates and revitalizes the skin.
Benefits of HydraFacial for Skin Care

Deep Hydration: One of the key benefits of a HydraFacial is the deep hydration it provides to the skin. This is achieved by delivering a blend of vitamins and antioxidants directly to the skin, which helps to nourish and revitalize it.

Improved Skin Texture: The gentle exfoliation and deep hydration provided by the HydraFacial help to improve the overall texture of the skin, making it look smoother and clearer. This can help to reduce the appearance of fine lines, wrinkles, and other signs of aging.

Clear Skin: The deep cleansing and extraction steps of the HydraFacial help to remove impurities and unclog pores, leaving the skin looking clear and refreshed. This can be especially beneficial for individuals with acne-prone skin.

Non-Invasive: Unlike other skin treatments that can be invasive and require recovery time, HydraFacials are non-invasive and do not require any downtime. This makes it a convenient and accessible option for individuals looking to improve the appearance of their skin.

Customizable: HydraFacials can be customized to suit individual skin care needs, with different serums and treatments available to target specific concerns such as fine lines, hyperpigmentation, and acne.
Conclusion

HydraFacials are a safe and effective option for individuals looking to improve the appearance of their skin. With its multi-step treatment that combines deep hydration, exfoliation, and extraction, it provides a comprehensive solution for skin care that leaves the skin looking refreshed, rejuvenated, and glowing!
